speaker: Joe
text: [_kissing Daphne_] Morning.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_sleepily_] Morning. [_realising_] Morning?  Oh my God, Joe,  get up!  Get up!  You were supposed to be out of here hours  ago. [_quickly putting on her dressing gown_] You promised me  that after we did the deed you'd be on your merry way.

speaker: Joe
text: I was.

speaker: Daphne
text: Get dressed.  We've got to get you out of here before Dr.  Crane gets up. [_Daphne opens her bedroom door and takes a look  outside_] Oh, no.  I smell coffee.  They're already up!

speaker: Joe
text: Now don't worry.  I'll just lay low until the two of them...  [_notices the clock_] Oh my God, it's nine o'clock. I'm a half-  hour late for work.

speaker: Daphne
text: Just give me a minute.  I'll get rid of them.

speaker: Joe
text: Where's my underwear?  _At this point Eddie comes running into the room and makes a dash for  Joe's underwear which is lying on the chair.  He grabs them and runs  back out the room with them.  Joe looks a touch dismayed._

speaker: Daphne
text: Eddie, get back here!  _The scene switches to the living room where Frasier is decked out in  his squash gear, reading the paper and eating breakfast.  Martin comes  through tugging at his trousers._

speaker: Frasier
text: Good morning.

speaker: Martin
text: Maybe for you.  I just spent five minutes trying to button  these pants.  That stupid dryer shrunk another pair on me.  _Martin grabs an eclair and stuffs in it his mouth.  Frasier looks on  disapprovingly.  _

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad. Before you blame the dryer, have you ever considered  stepping on the old bathroom scales?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, what's the point?  That thing's been ten pounds off for  weeks.  _In the background, behind Frasier and Martin, Daphne is fighting a  "tug-of-war" with Eddie over Joe's underwear.  Frasier and Martin turn  round to see what the commotion is._

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh.  Good morning, Dr. Crane.  Sorry I overslept.  Well, time  we all got our day started.  I'll just clear these dishes  away.

speaker: Martin
text: Wait, I wasn't finished with that yet.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_deliberately dropping the eclair into Martin's orange juice_]  Whoops.  Sorry about that.

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, I wasn't quite finished with that toast either.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, now, we can't have you running off to your squash game  on a full stomach.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes -- how many championship matches have been marred by the  heartbreak of toast cramp?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_to Martin_] Don't you have that Doctor's appointment?

speaker: Martin
text: Yes, but it's not for 20 minutes yet.  What's going on here?  Why are you giving us the bum's rush?

speaker: Daphne
text: Bum's rush!  Oh, I just love the American vernacular.  So  cute.  So quick.  So long!

speaker: Martin
text: [_heading through to the bedroom with Frasier following_]  Better get my wallet first.  Damn pants!  You know -- you spend  fifteen dollars on a good pair of pants - you expect them to  be shrink resistant.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Dad, when you pay that kind of money what you're  really paying for is the designer name!    _Daphne beckons Joe through who comes rushing out the bedroom, now  fully clothed but with his shoes in his hands.  He makes a bolt for  the front door._

speaker: Joe
text: Gotta go.  I'm so late.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh hurry, hurry, hurry!

speaker: Joe
text: I'll call you tonight.

speaker: Daphne
text: OK. Bye.  _They kiss goodbye quickly and separate.  However they look at each  other and have a longer kiss.  At this point Frasier and Martin emerge  from the bedroom._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh!  Hello Joe.

speaker: Joe
text: Hi Dr. Crane.  I just came by to give Daphne a kiss.    _Frasier looks suspiciously at him and then looks at the pair of  shoes still in Joe's hands._

speaker: Joe
text: And drop off these shoes. [_Handing shoes to Daphne_] Here!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well.  Can anyone think of anything to make this moment a bit  more awkward than it already is?

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Eddie!   **THEY'RE PLAYING DO-SI-DO, BUT NOT FOR ME**    _Scene 2 -- Cafe Nervosa  Frasier and Niles are sitting in cafe Nervosa drinking their coffee  whilst watching another couple._

speaker: Niles
text: Isn't that Dirk and Gabby Bindercott?

speaker: Frasier
text: Friends of yours?

speaker: Niles
text: Mmm.  Filthy rich.  Timber money.  In their case it really  does grow on trees!  Dirk!  Gabby!  Oh, Dirk?  _Dirk and Gaby are leaving, clearly trying to ignore Niles.  However  Niles's calling results in Dirk going to speak to him._

speaker: Dirk
text: Hello, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: [_introducing_] Dirk Bindercott -- my brother Dr. Frasier Crane.

speaker: Dirk
text: Ah -- I've heard your program. [_checks watch and then the door_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well -- I've seen your wife.

speaker: Dirk
text: So Niles -- I suppose I'll see you at the benefit on Sunday.  I know Maris is coming.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, Sunday.  Which benefit is Sunday?  I have so many  benefits... on Sunday.

speaker: Dirk
text: The ho-down for the homeless.  You were invited?

speaker: Niles
text: The ho-down?  Yippee-kai-yes!

speaker: Dirk
text: [_hears a tooting horn_] Must be Gabby.

speaker: Niles
text: Certainly sounds like her.

speaker: Dirk
text: See you Sunday.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.  Till Sunday.

speaker: Niles
text: I wasn't invited.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, it's one party.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, but when you're off the A-list for one party you're off  for all of them.  From now on I'll be relegated to B-list  charity events.  Grubby little theatre companies and last  year's diseases.

speaker: Frasier
text: This often happens in these cases when two people separate --  their friends choose one spouse over the other.  Surely they  chose Maris because she's better connected and has more  money than you do.

speaker: Niles
text: [_looking at Frasier thoughtfully_] Exactly which part of that  was meant to ease my pain?

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I just think you're overreacting.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh wait, wait.  I know what happened.  My invitation just got  lost in the mail.  No -- it's not so far fetched.  It could  have been missorted... or a stamp could have fallen off...  or it could have been stolen by my mail carrier.  Ho-downs are  catnip to postal workers!

speaker: Roz
text: Well I'd ask you to explain that but then you would!

speaker: Niles
text: [_getting up_] I'm going to check with the post office.  You  know -- I heard a story on the news the other day about a man  who bought a piano at auction and when he went to tune it he  found a 40-year-old unmailed letter under the sounding board.

speaker: Frasier
text: Perhaps we should contact Ferrante & Teicher -- see if  they have your invitation?

speaker: Niles
text: Poke fun now.  We'll see who feels foolish this Sunday when  I'm sipping champagne atop a mechanical bull!

speaker: Roz
text: [_to waiter_] Cappuccino, please.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, I want to get your take on something.

speaker: Roz
text: What?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well.  Daphne and Joe are having sex in my apartment and it  leaves me in a rather awkward position.

speaker: Roz
text: Doing what?  Bending over to look through the keyhole?  Oh Frasier, come on, what is the big deal?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, let's just say that I'm sitting there listening to  music, reading a book... and Daphne and Joe are "back there."

speaker: Roz
text: So?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it just makes me uncomfortable.  I'm going to ask Daphne  not to sleep with Joe in the house anymore.  Is that too...?

speaker: Roz
text: Amish?

speaker: Frasier
text: I was going to say selfish!

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, let's see.  Please Daphne -- don't have sex.  It disturbs  my reading!  No, that's not too selfish.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I just don't think a man should be uncomfortable in his  own home.  How am I supposed to relax when every giggle,  every noise makes me... you know...?

speaker: Roz
text: Picture it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course not.  Don't be ridiculous.  The very idea.

speaker: Roz
text: You're picturing it right now, aren't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you made me.  _FADE TO:    Scene 3 -- Frasier's apartment  Martin is sitting in his chair reading the paper.  Frasier comes in.  _

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Fras.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hey, Dad.  Is Daphne in?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, and if you have any sense you'll pretend that nothing  happened this morning.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, yes.  Denial.  The sort of advice I'd expect from a man  whose driver's license still lists his hair colour as brown.  [_going through to Daphne's room._]

speaker: Martin
text: It was until you came back to town!    _Frasier knocks on Daphne's door timidly.  Daphne opens the door  looking uneasy._

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne.  I think we need to discuss what happened this  morning.

speaker: Daphne
text: It's been bothering me all day.  It was entirely my fault.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no.  I share the blame.  We never did have a formal  discussion about the rules of the house, especially when it  comes to... you know...

speaker: Daphne
text: I do want to apologise for any embarrassment I may have  caused.  You see, we can't go to Joe's because he's still  building his house and he sleeps on a friend's couch.  But I  can assure you it will never happen again.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, then our business is concluded.  Meeting adjourned.

speaker: Daphne
text: The next time Joe spends the night, I'll notify you well in  advance.    _Daphne closes her door leaving Frasier looking still unhappy.  He knocks again on the door and Daphne opens._

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne.  I was just reviewing the minutes of our last  meeting.  There seems to be some confusion.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh?

speaker: Frasier
text: You see, my quibble is not with the lack of notification.  I  am just not comfortable with you and Joe sleeping together  under my roof.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I see.  I'm sorry about that, but it is my room, isn't it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh yes, yes.  And I want you to feel comfortable living here.

speaker: Daphne
text: I suppose it's more important for you to feel comfortable  because, as you said, it is your roof.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh.  Thank you for understanding.

speaker: Daphne
text: Not at all.  Joe and I are going away for the weekend but  first thing Monday I'm going to start looking for me own  place.    _Daphne shuts the door.  As before Frasier realises what she has just  said and is still unhappy with this arrangement.  He knocks on the  door again._

speaker: Frasier
text: Guess who? Daphne... em... I don't want you entertaining here  but I also don't want you to move out.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I see.  So you want me to stay, but just not have a  personal life?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well...

speaker: Daphne
text: No, no.  That works out fine for me.  I'll just spend all day  waiting on you and your father, then in the evenings retire  to me room, wrap meself in an Afghan and wait for the morning.  And if my whimpering gets too loud for you -- you can just have  me fixed like Eddie!

speaker: Frasier
text: That is not what I meant.  This is difficult for both of us,  Daphne.  I have to express my feelings.  I also don't want to  lose you.  You're very important to me and my father.

speaker: Daphne
text: That's why my solution is best.  I'll still be here during  the day to take care of your father but nights and weekends  I'll just go home to my own place.  On top of which you can  turn this room back into your beautiful study you used to  have.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well -- I suppose, what other choice do we have?

speaker: Daphne
text: Of course it'll be a period of adjustment for all of us...    _Whilst she is talking Frasier begins to look round the room and a  smile starts to form on his face._

speaker: Daphne
text: ...I know how much you two care about me and consider me part  of the family but... [_notices Frasier's smiling face_] You're  picturing your study right now, aren't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sheepishly_] Well, you made me!  _FADE TO:    Scene 4 -- Frasier's apartment  Daphne is away for the weekend so it's just Frasier and Martin in  the house.  Frasier is in the living room whilst Martin is in the  kitchen making breakfast.  The house is looking a bit of a mess with  newspapers strewn about the floor.  Eddie is watching everything from  the chair._

speaker: Martin
text: [_singing_] She's such a groovy lady!

speaker: Frasier
text: Morning, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, morning.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_picking up the newspapers and looking around him_] You seen  the phone?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, I probably left it in my room again.  Sorry.  Hey, I'm  making breakfast Burritos.  You want one?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'll passo!

speaker: Martin
text: Suit yourself.    _Martin comes out the kitchen carrying his breakfast.  He's wearing  nothing but a pair of boxer shorts and a vest.  Frasier frowns at him  but Martin just carries on eating his breakfast._

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad.  Whatever happened to the silk pajamas I bought you?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, Frasier, they're too la-dee-da for me.  Besides, they  shrank! [_a beep comes from the kitchen_] Whoa -- there go my  tater-tots.  You want a pile?

speaker: Frasier
text: Not that I don't enjoy a "pile" of breakfast as much as the  next guy but I still think no.  Dad, are you planning on  going around like that all weekend?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, why not?  Daphne's off on her little trip.  It's just us  guys.  Besides I've been wearing pants round here for three  years.  Enough!

speaker: Frasier
text: I see.  Look Dad, I just have to do this [_puts an apron on  over Martin_]

speaker: Martin
text: All right.  Now, listen.  It's no big deal but I couldn't find  the remote control for the TV last night.  Now I thought we  agreed that its place was on that table next to my chair.

speaker: Frasier
text: What was it like in the old days when you actually had to  get up to change the channel?

speaker: Martin
text: It was hell!

speaker: Martin
text: You expecting someone?

speaker: Frasier
text: The contractor.  I'm getting an estimate on restoring my  study.

speaker: Martin
text: Why don't you use Joe?

speaker: Frasier
text: I think Joe's done enough work in that room, thank you!

speaker: Frasier
text: Henry.  Thank you for coming on such short notice.

speaker: Henry
text: No sweat.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'll just show you the room. [_leads Henry towards Daphne's  room passing Martin at the table on the way_] Oh, this is my  father. [_to Martin, forcefully_] Don't get up!  Like a cup of  coffee?

speaker: Henry
text: That'd be great.

speaker: Frasier
text: Fine.  Look, the room is right down the hall there to the  right.  I'll meet you there.

speaker: Henry
text: OK.  _Henry heads on to Daphne's room.  Frasier goes through to the kitchen  before emerging again with a sponge._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Dad.  This is a small thing but you left the sponge in the  sink again.

speaker: Martin
text: So?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, as I mentioned last evening, if it stays wet, not only  does it begin to smell but it becomes a breeding ground for  bacteria.

speaker: Martin
text: So?

speaker: Frasier
text: So.  If I were to say wipe up that salsa that you spilled on  the table just now I would be leaving behind bacteria such  as salmonella, lysteria, flagella.  Now wouldn't that bother  you?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I guess you're right -- it would bother me.  I wouldn't  dream of touching that sponge now!    _Martin whistles in Eddie's direction.  Eddie responds by leaping up  on to the chair and licking up the salsa on the table much to  Martin's delight and Frasier's derision._

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, yes. Our own foul-breathed little handy wet!  _End of Act 1    Act 2_  **HE CRIED WITH HIS BOOTS ON**   _Frasier comes through to the living room to find the television  blaring and newspapers strewn all over the couch.  Martin comes  through from the kitchen._

speaker: Martin
text: [_turning off a light_] You've been leaving lights on in the  apartment all weekend.  You know what that does to the  electric bill?

speaker: Frasier
text: Suppose there's a nuclear power plant they had to build to  keep that television on day and night?  _Frasier picks up the remote and switches the television off.  Martin  has just settled into his chair._

speaker: Martin
text: You moved my chair again, didn't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: No!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh well, maybe Eddie did it.  Eddie, you move my chair?  'Cause Frasier said he didn't do it and Frasier never messes  around with my stuff.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, I moved your damn chair.  The way you have it  turned ruins the symmetry of the room.  The sight line  loses all flow.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, the sight line.  And here I thought it was for some dumb  reason.    _The doorbell rings and Frasier, becoming increasingly exasperated as  he goes to answer it, notices Eddie sitting on the couch._

speaker: Frasier
text: Would you get Eddie off of the couch, or else it's down  through the garbage chute for the thrill ride of his life!    _Frasier opens the door to reveal Niles wearing a suit and a slightly  oversized cowboy hat.  The two do not go!_

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, howdy partner.

speaker: Niles
text: Save your snippy remarks.

speaker: Frasier
text: Fair enough.  Say, am I crazy or is there a bright golden haze  on the meadow?

speaker: Niles
text: Stop it.  I'm in the middle of a social crisis.  I just drove  to the ho-down for the homeless assuming that Maris had simply  neglected to forward my invitation.  Well, not only was I not  on the guest list but Nelson, the parking attendant, said he  missed me at "The Luau for Lupus."  Now it is official.  I'm a  social outcast.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Niles, why do you even care about those people?  In your  hour of need they pretend you don't even exist.  They treat  you like you're a leper, a non-person.

speaker: Niles
text: But I really, really like them.  I know, I know -- it makes me  sound pathetic.  But I'm newly separated.  These people have  been my social circle for ten years.  Frasier -- they're my  tribe.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I hate to break this to you, "Waltzes With Snobs," but  they have left you on the mountaintop to die!

speaker: Martin
text: [_coming in from the kitchen_] Now Niles, maybe your friends  wanted to invite you but they probably thought you'd be  upset seeing Maris there.

speaker: Niles
text: Of course.  You're absolutely right.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's ridiculous.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, why are you so negative?  These people do care about me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh fine, very well.  Why don't you just call them?  Prove to  me I'm wrong.

speaker: Niles
text: Nothing would give me greater pleasure.  Where's your phone?

speaker: Martin
text: It's in my bedroom.

speaker: Frasier
text: Where else would it be? [_speaking to Niles as he goes through  to Martin's bedroom_] And Dad's electric shaver is in the  kitchen.  You see, all our appliances are on an adventure  this weekend.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, are you proud of yourself, stirring things up?  Why  didn't you just let him think his friends were doing him a  favour?

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, yes.  The Martin Crane approach.  Better living through  denial!

speaker: Martin
text: You did the same thing with Daphne.  You couldn't just pretend  that nothing was going on back there.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I'm a psychiatrist.  I don't pretend.  I confront.  I resolve.

speaker: Martin
text: [_sarcastic_] Oh yeah, you really resolved this.  Now she's  moving out. You know, I swear you just go looking for trouble.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that is so untrue.  _He walks into the kitchen before walking out with the sponge held at  arm's length by a pair of tongs._

speaker: Frasier
text: AND PERHAPS YOU CAN EXPLAIN THIS!!!

speaker: Martin
text: A grown man's obsession with a sponge?  No, I can't!

speaker: Frasier
text: For the last two days I've asked you again and again as  politely as I can to wring out the sponge.  But you don't  even have the consideration to respect my feelings.

speaker: Martin
text: Because your feelings are stupid!

speaker: Frasier
text: But they're my feelings!  And important to me!  And because of  that you should have the courtesy to respect them.

speaker: Martin
text: Just like you respect my feelings when I asked you not to  move my chair.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that makes no sense at all.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, all right. [_gets up out of his chair and takes the sponge  out of Frasier's hand and goes through to the kitchen_] You  want me to dry that sponge?  I'll dry that sponge! [_Martin  puts the sponge into the toaster_] Give it about a minute.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's mature.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, boy -- you know what a tortured little world you live in?  Newspapers strewn all over the place.  Sponge germs coming  after you.  It's a wonder you can sleep at night!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, my dreams get me by.  Like the one where I strap you in  your chair and run around the house turning on all the  lights...  _By now Frasier is running round like a demented madman turning on  each and every light in the house._

speaker: Frasier
text: ...even in the rooms I'm nowhere near.  Boy, that electric  meter must really be spinning now!

speaker: Daphne
text: Evening, all.  Did you boys have a nice weekend?

speaker: Martin
text: [_sarcastic_] Barrel of laughs!

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I had the loveliest time. [_notices Eddie on the couch_]  Hey -- Off! [_picking up the newspapers on the floor_] We found  this little bed-and-breakfast right up the coast. [_moves the  remote control to Martin's table_] I talked my decision over  with Joe, [_moves Martin's chair back to its original place_]  and he agreed it really is the best thing for everyone.  Of  course I'll still be here during the day to help your father  with his exercises. [_cleans up the table_] But nights and  weekends it'll just be you two carefree bachelors getting  into trouble together. [_puts one of the lights off before  heading into the kitchen_] I'm usually just underfoot around  here anyway. [_puts the newspapers in the bin then wrings the  sponge out_] So you see, my decision is best for everyone.  Well, I've had a long weekend, so good night.

speaker: Frasier
text: Night, Daphne.    _Daphne heads off to her bedroom. Frasier and Martin are quiet,  contemplating how Daphne has just sorted everything in one swoop._

speaker: Martin
text: Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: What?

speaker: Martin
text: You know how an Oreo has that soft creamy filling between  two hard cookies?  That's what keeps them together?

speaker: Frasier
text: See your point, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Daphne's kind of the centre.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'll go and talk to her.

speaker: Martin
text: Now, you and me, we'd be the cookie part.

speaker: Frasier
text: I get it!    _Frasier goes through to Daphne's bedroom and knocks on the door.  Daphne opens._

speaker: Frasier
text: May I come in?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes, of course.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Daphne.  Daphne... er... you can't go.  You have to  stay.  I've only just recently realised how important you are  to us.  You see, if you go, Dad and I will kill each other.  I'm not just tossing out hyperbole here.  I'm speaking in the  most literal sense.  Dad and I -- both dead!  Only he'll be  lying there with a bacteria-ridden sponge protruding from  his mouth like a bloated tongue.  You don't really want that  on your conscience, do you?

speaker: Daphne
text: No, of course not.  Truth is, I do still think of this place  as my home.  But I know you'd never be comfortable knowing  Joe and I were...

speaker: Frasier
text: I'd be willing to try.

speaker: Daphne
text: I know you better than that.  It'll bother you and we'll both  be miserable.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why can't I get past this?  Oh, it'd just be easier if I  could be like my father pretending you weren't in here  making love.

speaker: Daphne
text: Making love?  Is that what you think we were doing?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, of course.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh no.  There was nothing like that going on in here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?  Seems rather implausible.  I'd like to believe that  and believe me I really do want to... er... how can I?

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, how could Joe and I make love?  What with... er... Joe's  war injury?

speaker: Frasier
text: I didn't even know Joe was a soldier.  What war would that  be?

speaker: Daphne
text: The Falkland Islands.

speaker: Frasier
text: But that was a British conflict and Joe's not...

speaker: Daphne
text: His parents have a summerhouse there!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's very unfortunate.  Having a summerhouse in a war  zone.  But how-?

speaker: Daphne
text: He was kicked by a sheep.

speaker: Frasier
text: A sheep?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes, a sheep -- spooked by an air raid siren.  Work with me.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_now clearly pretending to believe whatever he is told -- no  matter how insane it is_] Oh, I see.  So, what you're saying is  that Joe...

speaker: Daphne
text: Can't.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah.  Well, I suppose that changes everything.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes, I suppose it does.  But just so as we're clear - even  though there's no actual lovemaking, Joe and I can on  occasion, say, read poems to each other in here at night?

speaker: Frasier
text: As long as you don't read too loudly.    _Frasier leaves and Daphne looks extremely pleased with herself.  Frasier goes back through to the living room to find Martin sitting  in his chair reading the paper._

speaker: Frasier
text: She's staying.  Turns out they're sleeping together but not  having sex. [_Martin looks puzzled_] See, they can't have sex  because of an injury Joe suffered when kicked by a spooked  sheep during an air raid while his family were vacationing  in the Falkland Islands during the war.  _Martin just nods his head in agreement.  Niles walks through from the  bedroom._

speaker: Niles
text: Well, Dad was right.  They are my real friends.  It was all  just a misunderstanding.  Apparently the social chairman's  dog ate my invitation.  And the poor animal had to go to the  vet and with all the confusion they forgot to send me  another, and when I offered my new address for next year's  party, they said, "no need -- we'll see you around."

speaker: Martin
text: [_joining into the spirit of the now-blatant lying as he tugs  at his trousers_] I'm going to start wearing sweat pants.  That damned drier again.  Hey, you guys want some cookies?  They're reduced fat.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?  That means we can eat twice as many.  _The boys all continue to talk to each other -- quite happy in their own  worlds of make-believe.    End of Act 2_
